models.py

```
        # Transforming time grain into an expression based on configuration
        time_grain_sqla = extras.get('time_grain_sqla')
        if time_grain_sqla:
            db_engine_spec = self.database.db_engine_spec
            if dttm_col.python_date_format == 'epoch_s':
                dttm_expr = \
                    db_engine_spec.epoch_to_dttm().format(col=dttm_expr)
            elif dttm_col.python_date_format == 'epoch_ms':
                dttm_expr = \
                    db_engine_spec.epoch_ms_to_dttm().format(col=dttm_expr)
            udf = self.database.grains_dict().get(time_grain_sqla, '{col}')
            timestamp_grain = literal_column(
                # here
                udf.function.format(col=dttm_col), type_=DateTime).label('timestamp')
        else:
            timestamp_grain = timestamp`
```

Most of the questions you posted here are covered by ~~caravel~~ superset documentation. You are very encouraged to give it a read.

1. I'm not sure why would anyone run this type of application on Windows, sounds like a world of troubles. We're not planning on supporting Windows as we can't run tests on it. You're free to play around with Superset in windows, but would advise against using Windows for production.
2. As for mobile support Caravel doesn't look too bad on mobile as we use responsive components (even the dashboard grid is responsive and dashboards can be designed where they'll look pretty good on mobile) but its definitely not the first class citizen. As lots of corporate users don't have VPN on their phones it's not been a real use case for us historically, but really like to see work in that direction.
3. Can be achieved with views at the moment. We're considering adding "forced predicate permissions" in the future, where predicates would be defined as in "sales_team_name='north-east'" and associated with related tables. Users with a role containing that "forced predicate" would see this predicated applied automatically anytime they query one of these tables 
4. SqlAlchemy works well, SSAS is a very different type of query dialect and would require a specific implementation. About CSV and external data, we recommend allowing users a path to load their own data in their analytics playground. Caravel could do that eventually through some "CSV uploader" feature. We assume you handle your joins upstream, not in Caravel. Meaning you can create views or data pipelines that prepare your data, and only then query that in Caravel. We may add a feature to define "many to one" joins in the future. 

About data storage, Caravel doesn't store anything, it queries your datasource on the fly. Note that some caching can be setup where the json behind individual view will be cached in something like memcache or redis. This allows for dashboards to load very quickly and prevent overloading the database when lots of people open dashboards with lots of slices at the same time.

About sharing, it's possible for people to share dashboards and slices to allow other people to alter them.

For customization, and depending on whether you want to alter the frontend or backend or both, you'll need an engineer fluent with modern open source workflows on Github, Python / Flask, Javascript / React / ES6 / Bootstrap.

Steps to re-create:
1) I pulled the latest version of Superset from GH this AM.  Commit: 2133056c04d20807ea0c503d0fed235ee20e94bb
2) Install/build node dependencies.
3) Started superset.  

When tested via Chrome, everything seems to work just fine.  However, when tested from IE11 (from the same machine used to test via Chrome) I see the same error from the screenshot above.  

Note: Superset itself is not installed on Windows - I use my Windows machine only to test with different browsers.  Superset is installed/running from OSX.  

I did a little bit of troubleshooting - there's definitely a difference in the URLs being requested between Chrome and IE.  

IE:

```
/superset/explore/druid/86/superset/explore_json/druid/86/?viz_type=table&granularity=one+day&druid_time_origin=&since=7+days+ago&until=now&table_timestamp_format=smart_date&row_limit=50000&include_search=false&flt_col_0=&flt_op_0=in&flt_eq_0=&having_col_0=&having_op_0=%3D%3D&having_eq_0=&slice_id=&slice_name=&collapsed_fieldsets=&action=&userid=2&goto_dash=false&datasource_name=Test.DBQL_Analysis_V3&datasource_id=86&datasource_type=druid&previous_viz_type=table&rdo_save=saveas&new_slice_name=&add_to_dash=false&save_to_dashboard_id=&new_dashboard_name=&json=true&force=false
```

Chrome:

```
/superset/explore_json/druid/86/?viz_type=table&granularity=one+day&druid_time_origin=&since=7+days+ago&until=now&table_timestamp_format=smart_date&row_limit=50000&include_search=false&flt_col_0=&flt_op_0=in&flt_eq_0=&having_col_0=&having_op_0=%3D%3D&having_eq_0=&slice_id=&slice_name=&collapsed_fieldsets=&action=&userid=2&goto_dash=false&datasource_name=Test.DBQL_Analysis_V3&datasource_id=86&datasource_type=druid&previous_viz_type=table&rdo_save=saveas&new_slice_name=&add_to_dash=false&save_to_dashboard_id=&new_dashboard_name=&json=true&force=false
```

If it isn't obvious from the above extremely-long URL, the only difference in the above URLs is that, in IE, the URL begins with `/superset/explore/druid/86/`; otherwise the 2 URLs are identical.  

Any idea what could be causing this issue?  Is there any other logs I can provide that might help to reproduce and/or diagnose?

We've been talking about a customizable Welcome page here too! Some of it is about:
- curation: favorites dashboards & slices
- surfacing popular/relevant/recent content
- for content creators: showing usage and spinoffs of the content they created
- an activity log, maybe similar to github's user profile page, maybe more relevant when looking at other people's page. I guess the "User Profile Page" is different to the "User Welcome Page", but somewhat related

There may be a need to summarize key usage information from Caravel's internal logs to summary table that we can use to build these pages. Things like "7day views", "28 days views", live to date views, distinct users views.

We've gotten pretty peculiar about writing/rewriting everything in React/ES6 with pretty high standard (test coverage, strict linter, ...), a great opportunity to learn if you're ready to comply to our new high standards :).

@ascott had some thoughts on this. Let's start the brainstorm / mocks right here!

BTW, somewhat related is the fact that if we'd have a way to have and cache thumbnails of all slices and dashboard we could have some beautiful gallery-type views to surface faves and suggested content. The whole headless-browser and image rendering thing is a headacke that would be nice to sort out.

Oh that's super cool!

Let me specify a bit better our use case, so we can gather all requirements.

We know that Flask App Builder doesn't support groups -- however we work in teams. We have created a "fake" user for each team, with emails like teamX@shopkick.com. Then, each user that creates a new dashboard also adds her team to the owners. This way, we can easily list all dashboard of a team X, by filtering owner in "teamX@shopkick.com".

What typically happens is that a user (think of manager/C-level) requests a dashboard, someone else in the company creates it, adding the right team as an owner, and the person who requested can see the dashboard without any further action, no favorite, no activity, etc.

Right now, however, people still have to enter the right search url, and we would like to make that url their default homepage.

In some sense the 2 things seem orthogonal to me. What I was proposing is an homepage field in the user profile, such that one can write any url there. What @mistercrunch is proposing is a more personalized homepage, but let say same url for everybody.

I think the 2 solutions can also co-exists. Clearly if the personalized homepage works well, there's no need to change the url, but I can still see use cases, e.g. for external users/partners/or specific people inside the company where you just want a different behavior, thus a different url. Make sense?

This is flawed again: 
- Tab height should be dynamic, not hard coded as many tabs overflow into a second row of tabs
- Remaining height only needs to be calculated in one place (SqlEditor)
- Should take into account the staging warning 
- Should take into account the Alerts

Pushed a new commit:
- parent is mounted after child mounting in react, so to get the height of Alerts and Tab size, I have to calculate it in App.jsx
- it seems the only suitable place to calculate height is in componentDidMount, after everything is rendered, but if we setState in componentDidMount, it will trigger another re-rendering, so it will render two times every time

thank you!! @toabey
@pmothe you need to sort out what "ORA-12541: TNS:no listener" means.

I've verified this issue is fixed in 0.13.2.

Steps:
1. Deploy 0.13.2.
2. Visit the "Explore" page and define a slice.
3. Switch from the table view to a time series visualization.
4. Works great now.

I think this issue can be closed, unless you prefer its originator to verify. Thanks again!
Closing, thanks @cscotta for reporting it fixed!
